reverseByteOrderUint256(uint256).details: Soldity uses a big-endian ABI encoding. Reversing the byte order before encoding ensure that the encoded value will be little-endian. Written by k06a. https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/a/83627

verify(bytes,bytes32,bytes32,bytes32).details: This method additionally ensures that the input hash is all-zeros (i.e. no committed input), the exit code is (Halted, 0), and there are no assumptions (i.e. the receipt is unconditional).

params.imageId: The identifier for the guest program.
params.journalDigest: The SHA-256 digest of the journal bytes.
params.postStateDigest: A hash of the final memory state. Required to run the verifier, but     otherwise can be left unconstrained for most use cases.

returns._0: true if the receipt passes the verification checks. The return code must be checked.
true if the receipt passes the verification checks. The return code must be checked.

CONTROL_ID_0().notice: Control ID hash for the identity_p254 predicate decomposed by `splitDigest`.

reverseByteOrderUint256(uint256).notice: reverse the byte order of the uint256 value.

verify(bytes,bytes32,bytes32,bytes32).notice: Verify that the given seal is a valid RISC Zero proof of execution with the     given image ID, post-state digest, and journal digest.

verifyIntegrity((bytes,(bytes32,bytes32,.notice: Verify that the given receipt is a valid RISC Zero receipt, ensuring the `seal` is valid a cryptographic proof of the execution with the given `claim`.
